steps.title: Have at least one stitch done on your right needle.
steps.content: Have at least one stitch done on your right needle. The left needle will have the rest of the stitches. In this tutorial, the stitch just before the yarn over will be called the "first stitch." The stitch after the yarn over will be called the "next stitch." Pay attention to your stitch pattern. When working the English style, you will need to move the yarn into the correct position. This will depend on what the first stitch was, and what the next stitch will be.

steps.title: If the first stitch and the next stitch are both knits, wrap the yarn under and over the needle.
steps.content: If the first stitch and the next stitch are both knits, wrap the yarn under and over the needle. Bring the yarn towards you, under the right needle. Next, drape the yarn over the top of the needle, away from you. This is called a "yarn forward" or "yfwd" in knitting patterns.

steps.title: If the first stitch was a knit, and the next stitch is a purl, wrap the yarn around the needle, from back to front.
steps.content: If the first stitch was a knit, and the next stitch is a purl, wrap the yarn around the needle, from back to front. Bring the yarn under the right needle, towards you. Drape the yarn over the top of the right needle, away from you. Next, wrap the yarn under the needle back towards you again. This is called a "yarn 'round need" or "yrn" in knitting patterns.

steps.title: If the first stitch was a purl, and the next stitch is a knit, bring the yarn towards the front.
steps.content: If the first stitch was a purl, and the next stitch is a knit, bring the yarn towards the front. Simply drape the yarn over the top of the right needle as you bring it towards you. This is called a "yarn over needle" or "yon" in knitting patterns.

steps.title: If the previous stitch and the next stitch are both purls, wrap the yarn, over the needle from front to back.
steps.content: If the previous stitch and the next stitch are both purls, wrap the yarn, over the needle from front to back. Drape the yarn over the top of the right needle, away from you. Next, wrap the yarn under the right needle, towards you. This is called a "yarn 'round need" or "yrn" in knitting patterns.

steps.title: Finish the next stitch.
steps.content: Finish the next stitch. Stick the right needle through next stitch on the left needle. Wrap the yarn under and over the tip of the right needle. Use the tip of the right needle to pull the yarn back through the stitch. Keep the working yarn on the right needle, and slip the stitch off the left needle. Some patterns call for you to yarn over twice. Simply wrap the yarn around the right needle like you did previously, then complete the next stitch.

steps.title: Finish the row, as the pattern directs.
steps.content: Finish the row, as the pattern directs. When you do the next row, you will eventually go over the extra stitch you got from the yarn over. You will get a lace-like hole that also acts as an increase. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Have at least one stitch on your right needle.
steps.content: Have at least one stitch on your right needle. The left needle should have the rest of the stitches. Unlike the English method, it does not matter what your first and second stitch will be. The working yarn automatically shifts itself into the correct position.

steps.title: Bring the right needle under the working yarn.
steps.content: Bring the right needle under the working yarn. If you are doing a knit stitch, the yarn will drape over the top of the needle, towards the back. [2] X Research source If you are doing a purl stitch, the yarn will drape over the top of the needle, towards the front.

steps.title: Finish the next stitch.
steps.content: Finish the next stitch. Stick the right needle through next stitch on the left needle. Wrap working yarn under and over the tip of the right needle. Use the right needle to pull the yarn back through. Keep the working yarn on the right needle, then slip the stitch off the left needle. Some patterns call for you to yarn over twice. Pick up the working yarn over your right needle again, then complete the next stitch.

steps.title: Finish the row according to the pattern.
steps.content: Finish the row according to the pattern. When you do the next row, you will eventually go over the extra stitch you got from the yarn over. This will create a lace-like hole in your project that also acts as an increase.
